_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: All compressors with their respective motors and all evaporative condensers
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Prevention program is based in the UAC 9unsafe acts and Conditions) monthly observation program conducted by the members of the safety council and the on-going following of the operation procedures from critical equipment and the use of checklist for startup and or shutdown of compressors and ammonia receiving system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Executive Summary    [A?68.155]

The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements: (a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source; (b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; (c) The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario; (d) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; (e) The five-year accident history; (f) The emergency response program; and (g) Planned changes to improve safety.

This four section report meets the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency for Prevention Program 3 [40 CFR 68] and the Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration [29 CFR 1910.119].

RMP regulations for Program 3 processes require the performance of a consequence analysis for one worst-case release scenario, estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint. The worst-case release scenario selected involved the complete loss of 10,000 pounds of Ammonia to the air. The 10,000 pounds worst-case release quantity selected represents the greatest quantity stored at Tex-Mex Cold Storage, Inc. at any given time, although the tank has a maximum capacity of 20,000 pounds of Ammonia. 

The RMP*Comp32 results indicate that the maximum distance needed for the concentration of Ammonia to reach the toxic endpoint (0.14 mg/L) as a result of a 10-minute release of 10,000 pounds of Ammonia is 1.5 miles. The total potentially affected population within the area of the circle (with a radius of 1.2 miles) is 12,470 persons as given by the LandView Population Census Estimator.

One alternative scenario was selected for the offsite consequence anal

ysis. This failure results in the release of the 10,000 pounds of Ammonia over a period of 30 minutes. This is equivalent to a release rate of 500 pounds of Ammonia per minute. The RMP*Comp32 dispersion modeling results indicate that 0.2 miles is the maximum distance for the concentration of ammonia to reach the toxic endpoint (0.14 mg/L) as a result of a 30 minute release of 334 pounds of Ammonia per minute. The LandView Population Census Estimator indicates that there is no potentially affected population within the area of the circle (with a radius of 0.1 miles). 

A search of U.S. Geological Survey and Google maps did not identify any offsite impacts of environmental receptors within the endpoint. Environmental receptors include natural areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, and federal wilderness areas.

No accidental Ammonia releases have occurred at this facility. 

The Tex-Mex Cold Storage, Inc., Accidental Release Prevention Policy involves an approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices in compliance with all applicable EPA Prevention Program 3 requirements and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements. 

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of Self-Contained-Breathing-Apparatuses (SCBA) and staff awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of ammonia. Tex-Mex Cold Storage, Inc. personnel employed the What If technique to conduct a Process Hazard Analysis. Employees discussed each question and recorded their answers. After answering the questions, they discussed the adequacy of the existing safeguards and recommendations for additional safeguards. The staff finished the Process Hazard Analysis with an equipment inspection. All equipment was inspected during the Process Hazard Analysis. The Process Hazard Analysis will be updated at least once every five years.  

Tex-Mex Cold Storage, Inc. ensures that each employee

presently operating the process, and each employee newly assigned to these processes have been trained or tested successfully in the operating procedures listed above that pertain to their duties. Annual refresher training provided to each employee operating the chlorination process ensures that the employee understands and adheres to the current operation procedures of the process. 

Tex-Mex Cold Storage, Inc. emergency procedure addresses potential emergencies that can reasonably be expected to occur at the facility. The emergency response procedures consider dangers within the facility that may affect employees as well as dangers outside of the facility that may affect the public or the environment. These procedures comply with EPA Risk Management Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements set forth in 40 CFR 68 and 29 CFR 1910.119. 

Tex-Mex Cold Storage, Inc. is the first responder. Employees are trained in response techniques and notification of other first responders in the event of accidental Ammonia releases. An emergency response plan is kept on-site where all employees have access to it.

Tex-Mex Cold Storage, Inc. posts escape plans within the facility where any person entering can see them. Facility personnel receive training in the escape plans to leave the building and to leave the area once outside the building.
